In a group that satisfies the normalizer condition, every maximal subgroup is normal

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), NormalizerCondition G → IsCoatom H → H.Normal
name: Subgroup.NormalizerCondition.normal_of_coatom
docString: In a group that satisfies the normalizer condition, every maximal subgroup is normal

In a group, if a subgroup is normal, then its elements are closed under conjugation.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H : Subgroup G}, H.Normal → ∀ n ∈ H, ∀ (g : G), g * n * g⁻¹ ∈ H
name: Subgroup.Normal.conj_mem
docString: In a group, if a subgroup is normal, then its elements are closed under conjugation.

In any group that meets the Normalizer Condition, this theorem states that any maximal subgroup is normal. The Normalizer Condition implies that every proper subgroup of a group is also a proper normal subgroup of the normalizer of that subgroup within the group. In this context, a maximal subgroup is considered a coatom, defined as a subgroup that has no other subgroups between it and the top element, and is not the top element itself. Therefore, if a group satisfies the Normalizer Condition, any such coatom, or maximal subgroup, is also normal.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), NormalizerCondition G → IsCoatom H → H.Normal
name: Subgroup.NormalizerCondition.normal_of_coatom
docString: In any group that meets the Normalizer Condition, this theorem states that any maximal subgroup is normal. The Normalizer Condition implies that every proper subgroup of a group is also a proper normal subgroup of the normalizer of that subgroup within the group. In this context, a maximal subgroup is considered a coatom, defined as a subgroup that has no other subgroups between it and the top element, and is not the top element itself. Therefore, if a group satisfies the Normalizer Condition, any such coatom, or maximal subgroup, is also normal.

A subgroup of a group is normal if and only if it is closed under conjugation by elements of the group.

type:
∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] {H K : Subgroup G},
  H ≤ K → ((H.subgroupOf K).Normal ↔ ∀ (h k : G), h ∈ H → k ∈ K → k * h * k⁻¹ ∈ H)
name: Subgroup.normal_subgroupOf_iff
docString: A subgroup of a group is normal if and only if it is closed under conjugation by elements of the group.

This theorem states that every subgroup of integers (`ℤ`) is cyclic. More specifically, it asserts that for every subgroup `H` of the integers, there exists an integer `a` such that `H` is the subgroup generated by `{a}`. This means that every element of `H` can be written as a sum or difference of copies of `a`, which is the formal definition of a cyclic group in group theory.

name: Int.subgroup_cyclic
docString: This theorem states that every subgroup of integers (`ℤ`) is cyclic. More specifically, it asserts that for every subgroup `H` of the integers, there exists an integer `a` such that `H` is the subgroup generated by `{a}`. This means that every element of `H` can be written as a sum or difference of copies of `a`, which is the formal definition of a cyclic group in group theory.

A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.

type:
{G : Type u_2} →
  {G' : Type u_3} →
    [inst : Group G] →
      [inst_1 : Group G'] → [inst_2 : IsCyclic G'] → (f : G →* G') → f.ker ≤ Subgroup.center G → CommGroup G
name: commGroupOfCyclicCenterQuotient
docString: A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.

In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial subgroup or the entire group.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] [self : IsSimpleGroup G] (H : Subgroup G), H.Normal → H = ⊥ ∨ H = ⊤
name: IsSimpleGroup.eq_bot_or_eq_top_of_normal
docString: In a simple group, every normal subgroup is either the trivial subgroup or the entire group.

The theorem `isCyclic_of_subgroup_isDomain` states that for any types `R` and `G`, with `R` being a commutative ring and `G` being a finite group, if there exists an injective function `f` from `G` to `R` where `R` is an integral domain, then the group `G` is cyclic. In other words, a finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is always cyclic.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Finite G]
  (f : G →* R), Function.Injective ⇑f → IsCyclic G
name: isCyclic_of_subgroup_isDomain
docString: The theorem `isCyclic_of_subgroup_isDomain` states that for any types `R` and `G`, with `R` being a commutative ring and `G` being a finite group, if there exists an injective function `f` from `G` to `R` where `R` is an integral domain, then the group `G` is cyclic. In other words, a finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is always cyclic.

A nontrivial densely linear ordered commutative group can't be a cyclic group.

type: ∀ (α : Type u_1) [inst : LinearOrderedCommGroup α] [inst_1 : DenselyOrdered α] [inst_2 : Nontrivial α], ¬IsCyclic α
name: not_isCyclic_of_denselyOrdered
docString: A nontrivial densely linear ordered commutative group can't be a cyclic group.

In groups satisfying the Normalizer Condition, maximal subgroups are normal.

type: ∀ {G : Type u_1} [inst : Group G] (H : Subgroup G), NormalizerCondition G → IsCoatom H → H.Normal
name: Subgroup.NormalizerCondition.normal_of_coatom
docString: In groups satisfying the Normalizer Condition, maximal subgroups are normal.

The theorem "commutative_of_cyclic_center_quotient" states that for any two groups G and H, where H is cyclic, and a given group homomorphism f from G to H, if the kernel of f is a subset of the center of G, then G is a commutative group. In other words, the multiplication of any two elements in G is commutative, i.e., for any two elements a and b in G, the product of a and b is equal to the product of b and a. 

The center of a group G is the set of elements that commute with all elements in G. The kernel of a group homomorphism is the set of elements in the domain that map to the identity in the codomain. A group is cyclic if it is generated by a single element.

type:
∀ {G : Type u_1} {H : Type u_2} [inst : Group G] [inst_1 : Group H] [inst_2 : IsCyclic H] (f : G →* H),
  f.ker ≤ Subgroup.center G → ∀ (a b : G), a * b = b * a
name: commutative_of_cyclic_center_quotient
docString:
The theorem "commutative_of_cyclic_center_quotient" states that for any two groups G and H, where H is cyclic, and a given group homomorphism f from G to H, if the kernel of f is a subset of the center of G, then G is a commutative group. In other words, the multiplication of any two elements in G is commutative, i.e., for any two elements a and b in G, the product of a and b is equal to the product of b and a. 

The center of a group G is the set of elements that commute with all elements in G. The kernel of a group homomorphism is the set of elements in the domain that map to the identity in the codomain. A group is cyclic if it is generated by a single element.

A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.

type:
{G : Type u_2} →
  {G' : Type u_3} →
    [inst : AddGroup G] →
      [inst_1 : AddGroup G'] → [inst_2 : IsAddCyclic G'] → (f : G →+ G') → f.ker ≤ AddSubgroup.center G → AddCommGroup G
name: addCommGroupOfAddCyclicCenterQuotient
docString: A group is commutative if the quotient by the center is cyclic.

A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : Group α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Nat.card α = p → IsCyclic α
name: isCyclic_of_prime_card
docString: A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

type: ∀ {α : Type u_1} [inst : AddGroup α] {p : ℕ} [hp : Fact (Nat.Prime p)], Nat.card α = p → IsAddCyclic α
name: isAddCyclic_of_prime_card
docString: A finite group of prime order is cyclic.

A finite subgroup of the unit group of an integral domain is cyclic.

type:
∀ {R : Type u_1} {G : Type u_2} [inst : CommRing R] [inst_1 : IsDomain R] [inst_2 : Group G] [inst_3 : Finite G]
  (f : G →* R), Function.Injective ⇑f → IsCyclic G
name: isCyclic_of_subgroup_isDomain
